"Certainty and Hypocrisy - The Foundations of Religion"? 
 
 Try,
 
 The Certainty of the Resurrected Christ and his Truths - the Foundation of Christianity
Thanks, EZ, for making my point.

I understand Ms. Albright's thesis about how religion can be playing a significant role in modern-day politics. But the relationship of this idea with "the foundations of religion" simply escape me..... Are you tryng to say that professing a religion but not understanding it is hypocritical? Isn't that what Cathecism is for?
 
 Your point is........?

Catechism may disclose the beliefs that one espouses within a certain religion but I think it is even more telling to know why these beliefs are held by examining the history of how these beliefs were codified, the number of people who were slaughtered in order to make sure that certain beliefs prevailed, that sort of thing. 
 
 I think it is always essential to reflect upon the number of people who were murdered in order to bring about belief in such things as the Trinity, Salvation of Souls, Virgin Birth, Resurrection, all that stuff.

I also think it is important to reflect on this. When we profess a religion, it is important to know that in the past there were people who also professed it but where incapable of following its commandments, and so in some cases caused severe and awful sufferings. However, the fact that there are many (including several ministers of the faith) that cannot live by the ideal doesn't mean that the ideal itself is wrong, it is in fact a reason for those of us who believe to try harder.
 
 This is why H.H. John Paul II apologised to the world for the crimes of the Church in the past.
 
 So, to say I believe in "the Trinity, Salvation of Souls, Virgin Birth, Resurrection, all that stuff" isn't hypocritical in itself, because the truths these ideas present have nothing to do with what any particular sinners did in the past. The ideas behind these dogmas are independent now from those who wrote them down. If someone said to you "it's not okay to murder", and then went off and slaughtered 10 people, would you stop believing the truth behind the statement because of the person who said it, or would it reaffirm your conviction it?
 
 What is hypocritical (and a show of ignorance) is to say that the leadership of the Church has never done bad things. But the IDEALS represented in the Church (not individual people, but the Church as a whole) are still worth fighting for.
 
 Don't you think this is reasonable?

On the other hand, I felt terribly sorry that a severely fragile old man was obliged to get down on his knees so many times to beg for forgiveness and understanding.
